block.p: Two Leading Pepsi Bottlers In $331.7 Million Merger The Whitman Corporation, the No. 2 bottler of Pepsi Cola behind the Pepsi Bottling Group, has agreed to buy the No. 3 bottler, PepsiAmericas, for $331.7 million.

The combined company, which will have about 20 percent of Pepsi's bottling market, will be run by Robert Pohlad, 46, the chairman of PepsiAmericas, settling Whitman's problem of who would succeed its 66-year-old chairman. Shares of Whitman rose 38 cents, to $14.13, while PepsiAmericas fell 81 cents, to $3.94. [Page C2.]

De Beers Overcomes Dual Challenge De Beers is ascending the diamond industry once again by reducing a huge stockpile it had accumulated in an attempt to keep prices high and by supporting moves to keep diamonds produced by war-mongering African rebels off of the legitimate market. [A1.]

Stocks Up With Fed Action Doubted Stocks rose as investors expected the Federal Reserve to leave interest rates unchanged today. The Dow Jones industrial average was up 33.33 points, to 11,079.81, while the Nasdaq composite index rose 22.81 points, to 3,953.15, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 7.76 points, to 1,499.48. [C10.]

Air Travel Panel Has Scant Progress A meeting of airline executives, labor unions, industry executives and government officials produced scant progress in addressing the record delays and cancellations that hit air travel this summer. [A14.]

Computer Virus Charges Dropped The Philippine authorities dismissed charges against the college dropout accused of being responsible for a destructive computer program known as the ''I love you'' virus. [C6.]

Telus Bids $3.1 Billion for Clearnet Telus, the largest telecommunications company in western Canada, moved to become the country's biggest wireless telephone network with a $3.1 billion bid to acquire Clearnet Communications of Toronto. Darren Entwistle, chief executive of Telus, said his objective was to become the Canadian leader of the wireless and Internet markets. [C4.]
